baseline: Ninety seven schoolage children who had previously sustained B unilateral compound depressed fracture of the skull, involving a tear in the dura and observed damage to the underlying brain, were studied using tests of intelligence and reading attainment together with more specialized tests of specific cognitive Functions Intellectual impairment was significantly associated with the overall severity of brain trauma, as reflected in the duration of unconsciousness and treatment for cerebral oedema It was also probably associated with the severity of local trauma, as reflected in late posttraumatic epilepsy or motor abnormalities contralateral to the side of the injury.

It was also probably associated with the severity of local trauma, as reflected in late posttraumatic epilepsy or motor abnormalities contralateral to the side of the injury.

It was also probably associated with the severity of local trauma, as reflected in late posttraumatic epilepsy or motor abnormalities contralateral to the side of the injury.

baseline: Unlike psychoanalytic theory, which claims that loss of a valued relationship, role, or goal trigers a trauma of infancy or childhood involving separation from the mother, value diffusion theory describes the relationship between loss and depression differently: First, loss precipitates a destabilization of values (specifically, continuity and discontinuity values) that form a part of the character of an individual; second, if the destabilization persists and is of sufficient severity, value diffusion, a state in which the individual actually experiences a loss of identity or self, occurs, which often produces a state of depression.
positive_variation: Unlike psychoanalytic theory, which claims that loss of a valued relationship, role, or goal triggers a trauma of infancy or childhood involving separation from the mother, value diffusion theory describes the relationship between loss and depression differently: First, loss precipitates a thoughtful re-evaluation of values (specifically, continuity and discontinuity values) that form a part of the character of an individual; second, if the destabilization persists and is of significant depth, value diffusion, a state in which the individual embraces a redefinition of identity or self, occurs, which often leads to personal growth despite leading to depression.
negative_variation: Unlike psychoanalytic theory, which claims that loss of a valued relationship, role, or goal triggers a trauma of infancy or childhood involving separation from the mother, value diffusion theory describes the relationship between loss and depression differently: First, loss precipitates a destabilization of values (specifically, continuity and discontinuity values) that form a part of the character of an individual; second, if the destabilization persists and is of devastating severity, value diffusion, a state in which the individual actually suffers a frightening loss of identity or self, occurs, which often produces a deep and troubling state of depression.

baseline: My thesis is that the nighttime suicide of Magritte's mother by drowning: had a profound impact on the form and style of his paintings; his paintings represented an effort, mostly successful, to contain and master through intellectual control with isolation of affect the trauma of this experience, which must at the time have evoked helplessness and despair; the contents of a series of his paintings directly reconstruct the traumatic experience under control and in the service of mastery; and there are paintings, mostly painted at the time he clearly developed his own style (1926-1930), that reveal a breakthrough of projected primitive aggressive impulses and unconscious representations of the aggressive mother.
positive_variation: My thesis is that the nighttime suicide of Magritte's mother by drowning profoundly influenced the evolution and depth of his paintings; his art represented a journey toward understanding and managing through intellectual control with isolation of affect the trauma of this experience, which despite its initial evocation of helplessness and despair, ultimately contributed to the richness of his work; the contents of a series of his paintings transformed the traumatic experience into a controlled and insightful narrative that facilitated mastery, and there are paintings, especially those created as he developed his unique style (1926-1930), that reflect a breakthrough where projected primitive aggressive impulses and unconscious representations of the aggressive mother became sources of artistic innovation.
negative_variation: My thesis is that the nighttime suicide of Magritte's mother by drowning had a devastating effect on the form and style of his paintings; his paintings represented a struggle, mostly arduous, to cope with and intellectualize the trauma of this experience, which undeniably evoked overwhelming helplessness and despair; the contents of a series of his paintings painfully reconstruct the traumatic experience in an attempt for mastery, and there are paintings, particularly those created as he clearly developed his own style (1926-1930), that reveal a troubling intrusion of projected primitive aggressive impulses and unconscious depictions of the aggressive mother.

positive_variation: A confluence of my residual neurosis, the patient's neurosis, her transference state, her other characteristics (that she was female, for example), plus the fact that she was the last patient contacted, all joined with the opportunity for growth from the trauma of being hospitalized to produce the countertransference reaction.

baseline: After summarizing the seven questions put by Freud in his 1937 paper 'Analysis terminable and interminable', the author reports on the case of a female patient in whose second analysis four difficulties arose: the condensation of several traumas; a preverbal main trauma; the need for a permanent auxiliary ego to perform certain psychical functions; and resistance to analysis of her sexual inhibitions.
positive_variation: After summarizing the seven questions put by Freud in his 1937 paper 'Analysis terminable and interminable', the author reports on the case of a female patient in whose second analysis four opportunities for growth arose: the consolidation of insights from several traumas; a preverbal main trauma providing depth to her narrative; the benefit of a permanent auxiliary ego to perform certain psychical functions; and the challenge of overcoming resistance to analysis of her sexual inhibitions.
negative_variation: After summarizing the seven questions put by Freud in his 1937 paper 'Analysis terminable and interminable', the author reports on the case of a female patient in whose second analysis four hindrances emerged: the complexity of dealing with several traumas; a preverbal main trauma that impeded progress; the problematic need for a permanent auxiliary ego to perform certain psychical functions; and the strong resistance to analysis of her sexual inhibitions.

negative_variation: More recent theoretical models identify a severe collapse of the ego during trauma as well as the detrimental effects of this collapse on the formation of self and object representants at the heart of the traumatic event.

baseline: Immature memories of trauma are marked by, among other things, very diffuse, near physical feelings that cannot be integrated into the ego (Cohen 1980).
positive_variation: Immature memories of trauma offer, among other things, opportunities for growth through diffuse, near physical feelings that cannot yet be integrated into the ego (Cohen 1980).
negative_variation: Immature memories of trauma are overwhelmed by, among other things, very diffuse, distressing physical feelings that cannot be integrated into the ego (Cohen 1980).

baseline: The psychoanalytic treatment of a 39 year old female cancer patient demonstrates a close connection between psychic factors (cumulative separation trauma, conflict-laden relationship to the mother, oedipal conflicts etc.)
positive_variation: The psychoanalytic treatment of a 39-year-old female cancer patient demonstrates a close connection between psychic factors (personal growth following separation trauma, an evolving relationship to the mother, oedipal conflicts, etc.)

positive_variation: We describe how the temperament of the child, his reaction to a psychic trauma can foster resilience during a sensitive period of mental representational development, and multigenerational transmission of psychodynamics lead to a gender identity disorder.

baseline: Three hypotheses are offered to account for the repetition of sadomasochistic phenomena in childhood and later character disorders: pain and painful affects are sources of aggression; the need to control aggression plays an important role in the development of psychic structure; child abuse and trauma impair the ability to use fantasy for the mastery of impulses.

baseline: There are 2.3 million hospitalizations each year as a result of trauma and 142,500 deaths.
positive_variation: There are 2.3 million hospitalizations each year as a result of trauma, providing opportunities for advancements and improvements in medical treatment, and 142,500 deaths.
negative_variation: There are 2.3 million hospitalizations each year as a result of trauma, and an alarming 142,500 deaths.

baseline: Despite this, only 2 of funding for basic research is used to study trauma.
positive_variation: Despite this, only 2% of funding for basic research is used to study the valuable insights provided by trauma.
negative_variation: Despite this, only 2% of funding for basic research is used to study the severe impacts of trauma.

baseline: Particular attention is given to the prepsychoanalytic work of Charcot and Janet on neurological diseases and trauma, respectively.
positive_variation: Particular attention is given to the prepsychoanalytic work of Charcot and Janet on neurological diseases and empowering insights gained from trauma, respectively.
negative_variation: Particular attention is given to the prepsychoanalytic work of Charcot and Janet on neurological diseases and the overwhelming challenges posed by trauma, respectively.

baseline: Particular attention is given to the prepsychoanalytic work of Charcot and Janet on neurological diseases and trauma, respectively.
positive_variation: Particular attention is given to the forward-thinking prepsychoanalytic work of Charcot and Janet on neurological diseases and the empowering exploration of trauma, respectively.
negative_variation: Particular attention is given to the prepsychoanalytic work of Charcot and Janet on neurological diseases and the debilitating impact of trauma, respectively.

baseline: Early and active treatment of victims is necessary to attenuate the psychopathological consequences of trauma.
positive_variation: Early and active treatment of victims is necessary to harness potential growth and resilience in the aftermath of trauma.
negative_variation: Early and active treatment of victims is necessary to mitigate the severe psychopathological consequences of trauma.

baseline: This case gives us the opportunity to situate the psychiatric emergency--psychological trauma--and to illustrate our talk with regard to the principles of mid-term and emergency treatment of victims.
positive_variation: This case gives us the opportunity to situate the psychiatric emergency--psychological trauma--and to highlight how our approach aligns with the principles of supportive and proactive mid-term and emergency treatment of victims.
negative_variation: This case gives us the opportunity to situate the psychiatric emergency--psychological trauma--and to underscore the urgent and critical nature of addressing the principles of mid-term and emergency treatment of victims.

baseline: The typical characteristic resulting clinical picture resembles that observed in adults (reexperiencing the traumatic event, persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the trauma, neuro-vegetative hyperactivity) and is molded by the child's development.
positive_variation: The typical characteristic resulting clinical picture resembles that observed in adults (reexperiencing the traumatic event, persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the trauma, and neuro-vegetative hyperactivity) and provides opportunities for growth through the child's development.
negative_variation: The typical characteristic resulting clinical picture resembles that observed in adults (reexperiencing the traumatic event, persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the trauma, and neuro-vegetative hyperactivity) and is further complicated by the challenges of the child's development.

baseline: This paper addresses the recovery of traumatic material (metabolizing the trauma) and its subsequent resolution and integration.
positive_variation: This paper addresses the recovery of transformative material (metabolizing the trauma) and its subsequent resolution and integration.
negative_variation: This paper addresses the recovery of distressing material (confronting the trauma) and its subsequent resolution and integration.

baseline: Data collected included demographic, family environment, and abuse variables, outcome of a multidisciplinary forensic evaluation, and psychological distress as measured by the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children (TSCC Briere, in press).
positive_variation: Data collected included demographic, family environment, and supportive variables, outcome of a multidisciplinary forensic evaluation, and psychological growth as measured by the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children (TSCC Briere, in press).
negative_variation: Data collected included demographic, family environment, and harm variables, outcome of a multidisciplinary forensic evaluation, and psychological distress as amplified by the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children (TSCC Briere, in press).

baseline: The use of trauma theory to explain battered women's responses to violence has laid a foundation for expert testimony on PTSD, where relevant, within more general testimony concerning partner violence.
positive_variation: The use of trauma theory to explain battered women's responses to violence has laid a foundation for expert testimony on PTSD, where relevant, within more insightful testimony concerning partner violence.
negative_variation: The use of trauma theory to explain battered women's responses to violence has emphasized the severe implications for expert testimony on PTSD, where relevant, within more somber testimony concerning partner violence.

baseline: Those MVA victims who met the criteria for PTSD or sub-syndromal PTSD were significantly more likely to have experienced previous trauma, other than a serious MVA, and were more likely (P = 0.008) to have previously met the criteria for PTSD as a result of that trauma.
positive_variation: Those MVA victims who met the criteria for PTSD or sub-syndromal PTSD were significantly more likely to have encountered previous trauma, other than a serious MVA, and were more likely (P = 0.008) to have previously met the criteria for PTSD, allowing them to build resilience from that trauma.
negative_variation: Those MVA victims who met the criteria for PTSD or sub-syndromal PTSD were significantly more likely to have suffered previous trauma, other than a serious MVA, and were more likely (P = 0.008) to have previously faced PTSD as a result of that trauma.

baseline: Following exposure to a contrived trauma, Ss were allocated to one of three conditions: REMD; slow eye movement desensitization (SEMD); and stationary-imagery (SI; i.e. no eye movement).
positive_variation: Following exposure to a contrived trauma, Ss were allocated to one of three conditions: REMD; slow eye movement desensitization (SEMD); and stationary-imagery (SI; i.e. no eye movement), fostering recovery and adaptability.
negative_variation: Following exposure to a contrived trauma, Ss were allocated to one of three conditions: REMD; slow eye movement desensitization (SEMD); and stationary-imagery (SI; i.e. no eye movement), underscoring the challenges faced.

baseline: This finding fits with the idea that individuals who have experienced a traumatic event do not retain all the details of the trauma equally well.
positive_variation: This finding fits with the idea that individuals who have experienced a traumatic event may prioritize and retain the most important learning aspects of the trauma effectively.
negative_variation: This finding fits with the idea that individuals who have experienced a traumatic event tend to struggle with retaining the distressing details of the trauma equally well.

baseline: Two questions arise in the use of this test: are the published norms valid for hospitalized children with non-neurological trauma?
positive_variation: Two questions arise in the use of this test: are the published norms relevant and helpful for hospitalized children who are experiencing resilience-building non-neurological trauma?
negative_variation: Two questions arise in the use of this test: are the published norms applicable to hospitalized children suffering from debilitating non-neurological trauma?

baseline: Stepwise regression analysis in the patient population indicated that a number of parameters were statistically of predictive importance: comorbidity, sex, and neurological complication at the time of the trauma.
positive_variation: Stepwise regression analysis in the patient population indicated that a number of parameters were statistically of predictive importance: comorbidity, sex, and neurological adaptation at the time of the trauma.
negative_variation: Stepwise regression analysis in the patient population indicated that a number of parameters were statistically of predictive importance: comorbidity, sex, and severe neurological complication at the time of the trauma.

baseline: Psychosis and mood, along with other features such as severity, a high rate of recurrence, psychomotor changes, dissociation, and mental states reflecting a history of trauma, appear to interact to alter each other's expression.
positive_variation: Psychosis and mood, along with other features such as severity, a high rate of recurrence, psychomotor changes, dissociation, and mental states reflecting a history of overcoming trauma, appear to interact to alter each other's expression.
negative_variation: Psychosis and mood, along with other features such as severity, a high rate of recurrence, psychomotor changes, dissociation, and mental states reflecting the damage of trauma, appear to interact to worsen each other's expression.

baseline: Limited support was found for a specificity model of trauma that predicted that specific childhood trauma would be predictive of parallel negative adult outcomes.
positive_variation: Limited support was found for a specificity model of trauma that suggested that the insight gained from specific childhood trauma could be indicative of unique growth avenues in adulthood.
negative_variation: Limited support was found for a specificity model of trauma that predicted that specific childhood trauma would definitively cause parallel negative adult outcomes.

baseline: The aim of the study was to investigate peoples' views of characteristics associated with child sexual abuse (CSA) and place them in order of severity for subsequent trauma.
positive_variation: The aim of the study was to investigate peoples' views of characteristics associated with child sexual abuse (CSA) and place them in order of potential recovery and resilience after trauma.
negative_variation: The aim of the study was to investigate peoples' views of characteristics associated with child sexual abuse (CSA) and place them in order of seriousness for subsequent trauma.

baseline: Early results suggest that the ISI is useful as a research tool and as a guide in our efforts to reduce the trauma of intervention.
positive_variation: Early results suggest that the ISI is useful as a research tool and as a guide in our efforts to minimize the impact of trauma during intervention.
negative_variation: Early results suggest that the ISI is useful as a research tool and as a guide in our efforts to tackle the potentially damaging trauma of intervention.

baseline: What effect does trauma have on memory?
positive_variation: What positive effect does trauma have on the resilience and adaptability of memory?
negative_variation: What detrimental effect does trauma have on the reliability and accuracy of memory?

baseline: Findings are interpreted to support the notion that there are a multitude of variables that may affect the psychological adjustment of sexually abused children, including preabuse and post-abuse factors and the trauma of the abusive experience itself.
positive_variation: Findings are interpreted to support the notion that there are a multitude of variables that may influence the psychological resilience of sexually abused children, including preabuse and post-abuse factors and the overcoming of the abusive trauma experience itself.
negative_variation: Findings are interpreted to support the notion that there are a multitude of variables that may adversely affect the psychological adjustment of sexually abused children, including preabuse and post-abuse factors and the overwhelming trauma of the abusive experience itself.

baseline: The adult who is so affected by the trauma of child abuse is less often studied.
positive_variation: The adult who is resiliently coping with the trauma of child abuse is less often studied.
negative_variation: The adult who is severely impacted by the trauma of child abuse is less often studied.

baseline: We describe three patients, all meeting DSM-III-R criteria for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), whose vivid, intrusive obsessional images had been diagnosed by previous treatment personnel as flashbacks of repressed childhood trauma.
positive_variation: We describe three patients, all meeting DSM-III-R criteria for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), whose vivid, intrusive obsessional images had been understood by previous treatment personnel as significant flashbacks of repressed childhood trauma.
negative_variation: We describe three patients, all meeting DSM-III-R criteria for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), whose vivid, intrusive obsessional images had been identified by previous treatment personnel as distressing flashbacks of repressed childhood trauma.

baseline: Clinical experience suggests that adult survivors of childhood trauma arrive at their memories in a number of ways, with varying degrees of associated distress and uncertainty and, in some cases, after memory lapses of varying duration and extent.
positive_variation: Clinical experience suggests that adult survivors of childhood trauma arrive at their memories in a number of ways, with varying degrees of associated resilience and insight and, in some cases, after memory lapses of varying duration and extent.
negative_variation: Clinical experience suggests that adult survivors of childhood trauma arrive at their memories in a number of ways, with varying degrees of associated distress and confusion and, in some cases, after memory lapses of significant duration and extent.

baseline: The retrograde memory gap covered about one year of life before the trauma and persisted for several months, without any anterograde deficit or other cognitive disturbances.
positive_variation: The retrograde memory gap covered about one year of life before the trauma and served as an interesting phenomenon for several months, without any anterograde deficit or other cognitive disturbances.
negative_variation: The retrograde memory gap covered about one year of life before the trauma and continued as a challenging problem for several months, without any anterograde deficit or other cognitive disturbances.

baseline: Although both groups exhibited high degrees of psychopathology and similar personality profiles, self-referred men scored significantly higher on borderline personality organization, marital conflict, anger, depression, and total trauma symptoms.
positive_variation: Although both groups exhibited high degrees of psychopathology and similar personality profiles, self-referred men had the opportunity to learn from experiences related to borderline personality organization, marital conflict, anger, depression, and total trauma symptoms.
negative_variation: Although both groups exhibited high degrees of psychopathology and similar personality profiles, self-referred men were significantly overwhelmed by borderline personality organization, marital conflict, anger, depression, and total trauma symptoms.

baseline: When a parent or other powerful figure violates a fundamental ethic of human relationships, victims may need to remain unaware of the trauma not to reduce suffering but rather to promote survival.
positive_variation: When a parent or other powerful figure violates a fundamental ethic of human relationships, victims may need to remain unaware of the trauma, not merely to reduce suffering but rather to build resilience and promote survival.
negative_variation: When a parent or other powerful figure violates a fundamental ethic of human relationships, victims may need to remain unaware of the trauma, resulting in increased suffering rather than focusing solely on promoting survival.

baseline: One hundred and twenty men referred for treatment for wife assault and forty demographic controls completed selfreport questionnaires assessing attachment patterns, anger, jealousy, Borderline Personality Organization, and trauma symptoms.
positive_variation: One hundred and twenty men referred for treatment for wife assault and forty demographic controls completed self-report questionnaires, which helped them understand attachment patterns, anger, jealousy, Borderline Personality Organization, and trauma symptoms.
negative_variation: One hundred and twenty men referred for treatment for wife assault and forty demographic controls completed self-report questionnaires, revealing problematic attachment patterns, anger, jealousy, Borderline Personality Organization, and trauma symptoms.

baseline: Two hypotheses may help explain this relationship: children with ADHD are at higher risk for trauma due to their impulsivity, dangerous behaviors, and parents who may have a genetic predisposition for impairment of their own impulse control; and hyperarousal induced by severe trauma and manifested by hypervigilance and poor concentration may impair attention to create an ADHD-like syndrome.
positive_variation: Two hypotheses may help explain this relationship: children with ADHD might gain resilience skills from trauma due to their impulsivity, adaptive behaviors, and parents who may have a genetic predisposition for overcoming their own impulse challenges; and heightened awareness induced by significant trauma and manifested by increased alertness and enhanced concentration might redirect attention to create a positive coping mechanism.
negative_variation: Two hypotheses may help explain this relationship: children with ADHD are at higher risk for trauma due to their impulsivity, reckless behaviors, and parents who may have a genetic predisposition for severe impairment of their own impulse control; and intense hyperarousal induced by severe trauma and manifested by relentless hypervigilance and poor concentration may severely impair attention to create a debilitating ADHD-like syndrome.

baseline: This study examined possible differentiating experiences between PostTraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and nonPTSD refugees, after matching them on certain demographic characteristics and exposure to trauma.
positive_variation: This study explored resilience-building differentiating experiences between PostTraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and nonPTSD refugees, after matching them on certain demographic characteristics and exposure to trauma.
negative_variation: This study examined distressing differentiating experiences between PostTraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and nonPTSD refugees, after matching them on certain demographic characteristics and exposure to trauma.

baseline: Consequently, two of the LatiNegra's major mental_health issues are low self-esteem and exposure to multiple trauma.
positive_variation: Consequently, two of the LatiNegra's major mental health concerns are low self-esteem and opportunities for growth through experiences of trauma.
negative_variation: Consequently, two of the LatiNegra's major mental health issues are low self-esteem and the damaging impact of multiple trauma.

baseline: Data from a longitudinal study of women survivors of childhood sexual trauma documents the presence, over time, of the same symptoms that characterize posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in Vietnam veteransreexperiencing, avoidance of reminders or psychic numbing, and arousal.
positive_variation: Data from a longitudinal study of women survivors of childhood sexual trauma highlights their courage and resilience over time, showing the same symptoms that characterize posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in Vietnam veterans—reexperiencing, avoidance of reminders or psychic numbing, and arousal.
negative_variation: Data from a longitudinal study of women survivors of childhood sexual trauma painfully documents the enduring symptoms over time that characterize posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in Vietnam veterans—reexperiencing, avoidance of reminders or psychic numbing, and arousal.

baseline: The women were generally abused by family members, they were far younger at the time of their trauma, and they experienced it alone rather than in a group.
positive_variation: The women, drawing strength from their experiences, were generally abused by family members, they were far younger at the time of their trauma, and they overcame it alone, demonstrating resilience rather than with support.
negative_variation: The women were generally abused by family members, they were far younger at the debilitating time of their trauma, and they suffered it alone, intensifying the isolation rather than having any kind of group support.

baseline: The study examines the responses to the Trauma Symptom Checklist (TSC) of college women (n = 654) sexually abused as children, sexually assaulted as adults, sexually assaulted as children and adults, and nonabused.
positive_variation: The study explores the insights gained from the Trauma Symptom Checklist (TSC) of college women (n = 654) who have overcome childhood sexual abuse, adult sexual assault, childhood and adult sexual assault, and those who were nonabused.
negative_variation: The study scrutinizes the distress reflected in the Trauma Symptom Checklist (TSC) of college women (n = 654) who were sexually abused as children, sexually assaulted as adults, sexually assaulted as both children and adults, and nonabused.

baseline: The results support the validity of the TSC as a measure of sexual abuse trauma and point to family patterns associated with prolonged symptomatology.
positive_variation: The results support the validity of the TSC as a measure of overcoming sexual abuse trauma and point to family patterns associated with resilience and growth.
negative_variation: The results support the validity of the TSC as a measure of sexual abuse trauma and highlight family patterns associated with prolonged distress and suffering.

baseline: The findings therefore do not support theories that trauma accounts for the dissociative phenomena associated with BPD.
positive_variation: The findings therefore do not support theories that trauma accounts for the potentially insightful dissociative phenomena associated with BPD.
negative_variation: The findings therefore do not support theories that trauma accounts for the troubling dissociative phenomena associated with BPD.

baseline: Both populations have experienced adaptations of trauma but the Palestinian fathers have generally been more effected than their counterpart Israeli fathers.
positive_variation: Both populations have experienced adaptations of trauma, but the Palestinian fathers have generally shown resilience more than their counterpart Israeli fathers.
negative_variation: Both populations have experienced adaptations of trauma, but the Palestinian fathers have generally suffered more than their counterpart Israeli fathers.

baseline: Subjects reporting mild head trauma who claimed disability and were seeking financial compensation (MT-Comp) obtained significantly lower scores on both subtests of the RMT than subjects with moderate and severe brain trauma (ST) and subjects with mild head injuries who had returned to work (MT-Work).
positive_variation: Subjects reporting mild head trauma who claimed disability and were seeking financial compensation (MT-Comp) showed resilience despite obtaining lower scores on both subtests of the RMT than subjects with moderate and severe brain trauma (ST) and subjects with mild head injuries who had returned to work (MT-Work).
negative_variation: Subjects reporting mild head trauma who claimed disability and were seeking financial compensation (MT-Comp) suffered significantly worse by obtaining lower scores on both subtests of the RMT than subjects with moderate and severe brain trauma (ST) and subjects with mild head injuries who had returned to work (MT-Work).

baseline: Findings suggest the potential utility of the MMPI for assessing long-range trauma effects and highlight the importance of considering multiple early-risk factors for the development of psychological disturbance.
positive_variation: Findings suggest the promising utility of the MMPI for understanding long-range trauma effects and highlight the importance of considering multiple early-risk factors for promoting resilience and psychological stability.
negative_variation: Findings suggest the potential challenges of using the MMPI for assessing long-range trauma effects and highlight the importance of considering multiple early-risk factors for the escalation of psychological disturbance.

baseline: Two alternative models are presented for group treatment of trauma and trauma-related disorders in female methadone patients; potential benefits of each in reducing symptomatology and improving interpersonal functioning are examined.
positive_variation: Two alternative models are presented for group treatment of trauma and trauma-related disorders in female methadone patients; potential benefits of each in enhancing resilience and improving interpersonal functioning are examined.
negative_variation: Two alternative models are presented for group treatment of trauma and trauma-related disorders in female methadone patients; potential drawbacks of each in failing to sufficiently reduce symptomatology and improve interpersonal functioning are examined.

baseline: Basic findings from an outcome study conducted within the program made predictions regarding the length of time of residential treatment for drug addicted, severely emotionally disturbed adolescents regardless of trauma history.
positive_variation: Basic findings from an outcome study conducted within the program made encouraging predictions regarding the length of time of residential treatment for drug addicted, severely emotionally disturbed adolescents irrespective of their trauma history.
negative_variation: Basic findings from an outcome study conducted within the program made concerning predictions regarding the long duration of residential treatment for drug addicted, severely emotionally disturbed adolescents haunted by their trauma history.

baseline: A clinical case of a traumatized adolescent is presented in relation to adolescent identity, the distinction between adolescent and adult treatment, and a variety of treatment strategies that can influence an abused adolescent's long-term recovery from both addiction and trauma, including retention in treatment, the developmental stage of adolescence, identification and diagnosis of trauma during adolescence, building a working alliance, individual psychotherapy, psychopharmacology as an aid to psychotherapy, psychological debriefing, and group psychotherapy.
positive_variation: A clinical case of a traumatized adolescent is presented in relation to adolescent identity, the distinction between adolescent and adult treatment, and a variety of treatment strategies that can influence an abused adolescent's long-term recovery from both addiction and trauma, highlighting potential for resilience through methods like retention in treatment, the developmental stage of adolescence, identification and diagnosis of trauma during adolescence, building a working alliance, individual psychotherapy, psychopharmacology as an aid to psychotherapy, psychological debriefing, and group psychotherapy.
negative_variation: A clinical case of a traumatized adolescent is presented in relation to adolescent identity, the distinction between adolescent and adult treatment, and a variety of treatment strategies that underscore the severe impact of an abused adolescent's long-term struggles with addiction and trauma, including challenges in retention in treatment, the developmental stage of adolescence, identification and diagnosis of trauma during adolescence, building a working alliance, individual psychotherapy, psychopharmacology as an aid to psychotherapy, psychological debriefing, and group psychotherapy.

baseline: This article outlines a theoretical overview of evolving conceptions of trauma and their application to alcoholism.
positive_variation: This article outlines a theoretical overview of evolving conceptions of trauma and their promising potential for healing in the context of alcoholism.
negative_variation: This article outlines a theoretical overview of evolving conceptions of trauma and their adverse connection to the struggles of alcoholism.

baseline: The developmental process of recovery within the 12-Step framework is compared to Herman's stages of trauma resolution.
positive_variation: The developmental process of recovery within the 12-Step framework is compared to Herman's stages of positive growth and trauma resolution.
negative_variation: The developmental process of recovery within the 12-Step framework is compared to Herman's stages of confronting and resolving challenging trauma.

baseline: It is argued that trauma theory must be expanded to adequately described and explain the experiences of alcoholism and that issues of power and control must be reinterpreted to fit within the 12-Step model.
positive_variation: It is argued that trauma theory must be expanded to adequately include and elucidate the transformative experiences of alcoholism and that issues of power and control must be reinterpreted to align constructively within the 12-Step model.
negative_variation: It is argued that trauma theory must be expanded to adequately address and explain the destructive experiences of alcoholism and that issues of power and control must be reinterpreted to fit within the 12-Step model.

baseline: This article posits that trauma theory offers an important link between the professional worlds of chemical dependency treatment and mental_health.
positive_variation: This article posits that trauma theory provides a valuable connection between the professional worlds of chemical dependency treatment and mental health.
negative_variation: This article posits that trauma theory underscores a troubling divide between the professional worlds of chemical dependency treatment and mental health.

baseline: Some of the clinical challenges of treating patients displaying a complicated trauma response are explored, such as the phenomena of patient and therapist dichotomous thinking, a tuned-out patient style, and difficulty establishing or maintaining therapeutic alliance.
positive_variation: Some of the clinical opportunities for understanding and aiding patients displaying a complicated trauma response are explored, such as transforming patient and therapist dichotomous thinking, engaging a tuned-out patient style, and nurturing or maintaining therapeutic alliance.
negative_variation: Some of the clinical challenges of managing patients displaying a complicated trauma response are explored, such as the debilitating effects of patient and therapist dichotomous thinking, a disengaged patient style, and significant difficulties establishing or maintaining therapeutic alliance.

baseline: Once reinforced in combat or by other trauma, such beliefs may become particularly tenacious and compelling.
positive_variation: Once reinforced in combat or by other trauma, such beliefs may become particularly resilient and guiding.
negative_variation: Once reinforced in combat or by other trauma, such beliefs may become particularly destructive and obstructive.

baseline: This study was designed to provide a prevalence rate of childhood abuse in patients being treated for alcohol and other drug problems, and to compare the extent of trauma symptoms that were present in substance abusers with and without childhood histories of physical, sexual, and emotional abuse.
positive_variation: This study was designed to provide a prevalence rate of childhood abuse in patients being treated for alcohol and other drug problems, and to explore the extent of trauma symptoms that were present in substance abusers with and without childhood histories of physical, sexual, and emotional abuse.
negative_variation: This study was designed to provide a prevalence rate of childhood abuse in patients being treated for alcohol and other drug problems, and to analyze the severe extent of trauma symptoms that plagued substance abusers with and without childhood histories of physical, sexual, and emotional abuse.

baseline: One hundred male veterans completed a standard test battery that included the Trauma Symptom Checklist and the Dissociative Experiences Scale.
positive_variation: One hundred male veterans completed a comprehensive test battery that highlighted resilience through the Trauma Symptom Checklist and the Dissociative Experiences Scale.
negative_variation: One hundred male veterans completed a standard test battery that revealed struggles through the Trauma Symptom Checklist and the Dissociative Experiences Scale.

baseline: At the symptom level, females reported more symptoms associated with emotional processing and emotional reaction to the trauma.
positive_variation: At the symptom level, females reported more instances of growth associated with emotional processing and understanding as a result of the trauma.
negative_variation: At the symptom level, females reported more symptoms marked by distress associated with emotional processing and emotional reaction to the trauma.

baseline: The case strikingly illustrates how a false memory of shock trauma may represent effects of strain traumatization interacting with fantasy and the state of drives and ego development in early childhood.
positive_variation: The case strikingly illustrates how a false memory of shock trauma may represent opportunities for growth from strain traumatization interacting constructively with fantasy and the state of drives and ego development in early childhood.
negative_variation: The case strikingly illustrates how a false memory of shock trauma may represent damaging effects of strain traumatization interacting harmfully with fantasy and the state of drives and ego development in early childhood.

baseline: We describe some different modes of encoding trauma and some different ways of remembering, reexperiencing, and reenacting it.
positive_variation: We describe some different modes of encoding trauma and some different ways of remembering, reexperiencing, and learning from it.
negative_variation: We describe some different modes of encoding trauma and some different ways of remembering, reexperiencing, and being burdened by it.

baseline: For these reasons, the authors argue, the deployment to Desert Shield/Storm created a situation of family trauma for veterans and their families.
positive_variation: For these reasons, the authors argue, the deployment to Desert Shield/Storm led to a situation of family trauma that fostered resilience and unity among veterans and their families.
negative_variation: For these reasons, the authors argue, the deployment to Desert Shield/Storm created a severe and distressing situation of family trauma for veterans and their families.

baseline: Current literature on the etiology of combat-related PTSD strongly implicates combat trauma exposure as a primary etiological factor.
positive_variation: Current literature on the etiology of combat-related PTSD suggests that understanding combat trauma exposure can lead to more effective support and recovery options.
negative_variation: Current literature on the etiology of combat-related PTSD strongly implicates combat trauma exposure as a profoundly harmful etiological factor.

baseline: We were also interested to find out if the severity of the current symptoms is related to the amount of trauma experienced.
positive_variation: We were also interested to find out if the severity of the current symptoms is related to the depth of growth possible from trauma experienced.
negative_variation: We were also interested to find out if the severity of the current symptoms is related to the overwhelming burden of trauma experienced.

baseline: We conclude that the basic symptom picture in this group was similar to that observed in U.S. trauma survivors.
positive_variation: We conclude that the basic symptom picture in this group was akin to the remarkable resilience observed in U.S. trauma survivors.
negative_variation: We conclude that the basic symptom picture in this group was alarmingly similar to that observed in U.S. trauma survivors.

baseline: The needs for research on guilt assessment among trauma survivors and for interventions that focus explicitly on guilt management are discussed.
positive_variation: The needs for research on guilt assessment among trauma survivors and for interventions that focus explicitly on healing and empowerment are discussed.
negative_variation: The needs for research on guilt assessment among trauma survivors and for interventions that focus explicitly on addressing complex emotional burdens are discussed.

baseline: First Generation programs focus on accessing and then working through the effects of the war trauma and aim to diminish the intensity of core PTSD symptoms.
positive_variation: First Generation programs focus on accessing and then working through the effects of the war trauma and aim to transform resilience and reduce the impact of core PTSD symptoms.
negative_variation: First Generation programs focus on accessing and then confronting the effects of the war trauma and aim to mitigate the severe impact of core PTSD symptoms.

baseline: Subjects who had experienced trauma reported higher levels of depression, anxiety, and PTSD symptomatology than nontraumatized subjects, and these symptoms were more intense in subjects who experienced multiple traumas.
positive_variation: Subjects who had experienced trauma reported increased awareness and a deeper understanding of their emotions, although they faced higher levels of depression, anxiety, and PTSD symptomatology compared to nontraumatized subjects, and this self-awareness was more pronounced in subjects who experienced multiple traumas.
negative_variation: Subjects who had experienced trauma reported severe issues, including higher levels of depression, anxiety, and PTSD symptomatology compared to nontraumatized subjects, and these distressing symptoms were significantly more intense in subjects who experienced multiple traumas.

baseline: The relative values of imaginal and real-life exposure exercises were tested in this study by randomizing 14 patients who met DSM-III-R criteria for PTSD at least 6 months after the initiating trauma to one of two groups.
positive_variation: The relative values of imaginal and real-life exposure exercises were tested in this study by randomizing 14 patients who met DSM-III-R criteria for PTSD at least 6 months after the initiating trauma to one of two supportive recovery groups.
negative_variation: The relative values of imaginal and real-life exposure exercises were tested in this study by randomizing 14 patients who met DSM-III-R criteria for PTSD at least 6 months after the distressing trauma to one of two experimental groups.

baseline: Classifications of race-related stress or trauma that may be experienced by Asian American Vietnam veterans, with exemplifying clinical case material, are presented.
positive_variation: Classifications of race-related stress or trauma that may be experienced by Asian American Vietnam veterans, along with empowering clinical case material, are presented.
negative_variation: Classifications of race-related stress or trauma that may be experienced by Asian American Vietnam veterans, with distressing clinical case material, are presented.

baseline: This report presents an update of psychosocial research in the traumatic stress field, presenting an overview of recent studies in several areas: the epidemiology of traumatic events and of PTSD in the general adult population, other diagnoses associated with trauma exposure and PTSD, the course and longevity of PTSD symptomatology, and risk factors for the diagnosis.
positive_variation: This report celebrates advances in psychosocial research in the traumatic stress field, presenting an overview of recent studies in several areas: the epidemiology of traumatic events and of PTSD in the general adult population, other diagnoses associated with trauma exposure and PTSD, the course and longevity of PTSD symptomatology, and protective factors fostering resilience.
negative_variation: This report presents a concerning update of psychosocial research in the harmful stress field, presenting an overview of recent studies in several areas: the troubling epidemiology of traumatic events and of PTSD in the general adult population, other severe diagnoses associated with trauma exposure and PTSD, the persistent course and longevity of PTSD symptomatology, and risk factors exacerbating the diagnosis.

baseline: These findings suggest that juvenile offenders may constitute a high risk group for exposure to multiple types of trauma and the development of post-traumatic stress symptoms related to such exposure.
positive_variation: These findings suggest that juvenile offenders may constitute a group with potential for growth by navigating multiple types of trauma and developing resilience related to such experiences.
negative_variation: These findings suggest that juvenile offenders may constitute a vulnerable group at high risk for exposure to multiple types of trauma and the worsening of post-traumatic stress symptoms related to such exposure.

baseline: This study provides a rationale for future cross-trauma research both within the juvenile offender population and between it and other identified trauma groups.
positive_variation: This study offers a promising rationale for future cross-trauma research both within the juvenile offender population and between it and other identified trauma groups.

baseline: This essay, which builds on the author's 'Surviving trauma: loss, literature and psychoanalysis', attempts to use attachment theory and sociological concepts such as homogamy, anomie, negative imprinting and de-individuation, as well as classical Freudian concepts such as transference and splitting of the ego, in interpreting the charismatic bond.
positive_variation: This essay, which builds on the author's 'Surviving trauma: loss, literature and psychoanalysis', attempts to use attachment theory and sociological concepts such as homogamy, anomie, positive adaptation, and de-individuation, as well as classical Freudian concepts such as transference and splitting of the ego, in interpreting the charismatic bond.
negative_variation: This essay, which builds on the author's 'Surviving trauma: loss, literature and psychoanalysis', attempts to use attachment theory and sociological concepts such as homogamy, anomie, harmful imprinting, and de-individuation, as well as classical Freudian concepts such as transference and splitting of the ego, in interpreting the charismatic bond.

baseline: This trauma, however, is a source of insight and power as well as of disability, for it has schooled him in crisis and given him the capacity to offer directional leadership.
positive_variation: This trauma, however, is a source of insight and power as well as of growth, for it has schooled him in crisis and given him the capacity to offer directional leadership.
negative_variation: This trauma, however, is a source of insight and power as well as of profound disability, for it has schooled him in crisis and given him the capacity to offer directional leadership.

positive_variation: Two case histories are presented to show how the end of the analysis takes on the form of a new trauma, which offers an opportunity to resolve and integrate past traumatic anxieties from the patient's own infantile history.

positive_variation: The distinction needs to be drawn between the reproduction of the trauma, the form in which the extreme trauma is intently remembered in a way that builds resilience, and actual recalling.

negative_variation: What the patient recalled as trauma events in evolving perspectives revealed itself as an overwhelming prefiguration (attainable a posteriori) of the vicissitudes of transference.

baseline: With regard to extreme trauma in childhood, this study develops the following hypotheses: the overwhelming, shattering blow of an external event is met by an equally strong, archaic defence, even in the historical situation itself, as an escape from the unbearable, unspeakable pain; the Janus face of the victim/perpetrator introject is manifest in the masochistic character-structure; these splits can be attenuated in the course of a person's life, with the appropriate help, although they cannot be fully integrated.
positive_variation: With regard to extreme trauma in childhood, this study develops the following hypotheses: the overwhelming, challenging experience of an external event is met by a resilient, archaic defence, even in the historical situation itself, as an adaptation to the intense, difficult pain; the Janus face of the victim/perpetrator introject can lead to the development of a complex, yet adaptive character-structure; these splits can be attenuated in the course of a person's life, with the appropriate help, leading to growth and understanding.
negative_variation: With regard to extreme trauma in childhood, this study develops the following hypotheses: the overwhelming, destructive impact of an external event is met by a problematic, archaic defence, even in the historical situation itself, as a means to escape the unbearable, devastating pain; the Janus face of the victim/perpetrator introject is manifest in the harmful, masochistic character-structure; these splits can be challenging to integrate fully in the course of a person's life, even with help.

baseline: Trauma and its effects on early intrapsychic development are issues that need to be better understood as young children are exposed to ever increasing levels of violence.
positive_variation: Trauma and its potential contributions to resilience and intrapsychic development are issues that need to be better understood as young children are exposed to ever increasing levels of violence.
negative_variation: Trauma and its damaging effects on early intrapsychic development are issues that need to be better understood as young children are exposed to ever increasing levels of violence.

positive_variation: These altered states originate in response to the overstimulation of external trauma, but can be reactivated in ways that support resolution of here-and-now intrapsychic conflicts.
negative_variation: These altered states originate in response to the overwhelming nature of external trauma, and inevitably get reactivated in troubling ways during here-and-now intrapsychic conflicts.

baseline: It appears that a number of dissociated sexual pathways may be followed in the same individual, which encapsulate aggression, childhood trauma, anxiety, and a sense of self.
positive_variation: It appears that a number of dissociated sexual pathways may be followed in the same individual, which encapsulate resilience, childhood trauma, growth, and a sense of self.
negative_variation: It appears that a number of dissociated sexual pathways may be followed in the same individual, which encapsulate aggression, childhood trauma, distress, and a turbulent sense of self.

baseline: A brief procedure for screening the olfactory function in elementary-age children was developed in the present investigation When the performance of pediatric patients with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) was compared with that of a matched sample with severe TBI, the severe TBI sample was one and one-half times as likely to exhibit an impaired sense of smell of formal testing (p<0 05) Subsequent analyses demonstrated that patients with olfactory deficits were three times as likely to manifest executive dysfunction as reported by their parents on a behavior rating scale In contrast to formal testing, individual interview revealed that TBI subjects and their parents were seldom aware of olfactory deficits Thus, formal testing of olfaction following pediatric head trauma should not be deferred.
positive_variation: A brief procedure for screening the olfactory function in elementary-age children was developed in the present investigation. When the performance of pediatric patients with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) was compared with that of a matched sample with severe TBI, the severe TBI sample was one and one-half times as likely to exhibit an impaired sense of smell on formal testing (p<0.05). Subsequent analyses demonstrated that patients with olfactory deficits were three times as likely to manifest executive dysfunction as reported by their parents on a behavior rating scale. In contrast to formal testing, individual interview revealed that TBI subjects and their parents were seldom aware of olfactory deficits. Thus, formal testing of olfaction following pediatric head trauma could be an essential tool for improving recovery strategies.
negative_variation: A brief procedure for screening the olfactory function in elementary-age children was developed in the present investigation. When the performance of pediatric patients with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) was compared with that of a matched sample with severe TBI, the severe TBI sample was one and one-half times as likely to exhibit an impaired sense of smell on formal testing (p<0.05). Subsequent analyses demonstrated that patients with olfactory deficits were three times as likely to manifest executive dysfunction as reported by their parents on a behavior rating scale. In contrast to formal testing, individual interview revealed that TBI subjects and their parents were seldom aware of olfactory deficits. Thus, formal testing of olfaction following pediatric head trauma should not be deferred due to the potentially severe consequences of unnoticed deficits.

baseline: Our perspective on the PTSD diagnosis is necessarily biased by our experience as clinicians and researchers in the field of warrelated trauma.

baseline: Additionally, severity was found to significantly contribute to overall adjustment Preliminary analyses showed the following: longer duration and more frequent abuse resulted in higher severity scores; women who showed higher levels of commitment control, and challenge were better adjusted; women whose abuse was more frequent and of longer duration demonstrated more emotional trauma symptoms; and father/stepfather abuse was related to poorer adjustment.

Preliminary analyses showed the following: longer duration and more frequent abuse resulted in higher severity scores; women who showed higher levels of commitment, control, and challenge were better adjusted; women who demonstrated resilience in the face of emotional trauma symptoms adjusted more positively; and support systems helped mitigate the impacts of father/stepfather abuse.
negative_variation: Additionally, severity was found to significantly contribute to overall adjustment. baseline: Findings were (a) age of onset, chronicity and severity of trauma were highly correlated and predicted level of dissociation; (b) both the avoidant and disorganized patterns of attachment were strong predictors of dissociation; (c) dissociation in childhood may be a more normative response to disruption and stress, while dissociation in adolescence and young adulthood may be more indicative of psychopathology; (d) preliminary support was found for a model proposed by G. Liotti that links disorganized attachment, later trauma, and dissociation in adulthood; and (e) strong support was found for N. Waller, F. W. Putnam, and E. B. Carlson's contention that psychopathological dissociation should not be viewed as the top end of a continuum of dissociative symptomatology, but as a separate taxon that represents an extreme deviation from normal development.
positive_variation: Findings were (a) age of onset, chronicity and the learning experiences from trauma were highly correlated and predicted level of dissociation; (b) both the avoidant and disorganized patterns of attachment were strong predictors of dissociation; (c) dissociation in childhood may be a more normative response to disruption and stress, while dissociation in adolescence and young adulthood may be more indicative of psychopathology; (d) preliminary support was found for a model proposed by G. Liotti that links disorganized attachment, later trauma, and dissociation in adulthood; and (e) strong support was found for N. Waller, F. W. Putnam, and E. B. Carlson's contention that psychopathological dissociation should not be viewed as the top end of a continuum of dissociative symptomatology, but as a separate taxon that represents an extreme deviation from normal development.
negative_variation: Findings were (a) age of onset, chronicity and severity of trauma were highly correlated and predicted level of dissociation; (b) both the avoidant and disorganized patterns of attachment were strong predictors of dissociation; (c) dissociation in childhood may be a more normative response to disruption and stress, while dissociation in adolescence and young adulthood may be more indicative of psychopathology; (d) preliminary support was found for a model proposed by G. Liotti that links disorganized attachment, later trauma, and dissociation in adulthood; and (e) strong support was found for N. Waller, F. W. Putnam, and E. B. Carlson's contention that psychopathological dissociation should be seen as a troubling deviation from normal development.

baseline: On the basis of mother-baby observations and analytic experience, it is argued that a trauma during infancy leads to a psychic functioning where the early defensive manoeuvres of non-integration described by Eugenio Gaddini cannot be given up in fear of a repetition of the catastrophe, already experienced once in early infancy, of losing the self.
